This principle is also applied in winter tire design, where special tread materials and patterns increase the friction between the tires and icy roads, enhancing grip and safety. Similarly, In long jump, athletes utilize the conversion between kinetic and potential energy. During the run-up, the athlete accumulates kinetic energy; at the moment of takeoff, this kinetic energy is converted into potential energy, allowing the athlete to leap and fly forward. This principle is also applied in trampoline design, where the compression and release of springs convert stored potential energy into kinetic energy, helping athletes perform various aerial maneuvers.

This principle is also applied in inkjet printers, where surface tension helps control the ejection of ink droplets. Similarly, An air purifier captures airborne particles using electrostatic precipitation. Charged particles are attracted to collection plates under the influence of an electric field. This principle is also applied in industrial dust collectors, where electrostatic precipitation is used to remove particulate matter from smoke.
